Fig. 1 Ti-Mn supports with different Mn contents were prepared by impregnation combustion method. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of 0.1Pt/Ti (a), 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn (b), 0.1Pt/7Ti-3Mn (c), 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn (d), 0.1Pt/3Ti-7Mn (e), 0.1Pt/1Ti-9Mn (f). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of the catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a,e) TEM images with particle size distribution of the as-prepared 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst and corresponding (b) Pt, (c) Ti and (d) Mn chemical maps. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 FT-IR spectra of catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR profiles of various catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 O2-TPD profiles of 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS spectra of various catalysts (a) and high-resolution XPS spectra of Mn2p (b), O 1 s (c), Ti 2 P (d), Mn3S (e), Pt 4 f (e). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 High-resolution XPS spectra ofTi 2p, O 1 s. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Experimental evaluation results of Pt/Mn-Ti catalysts (GSHV=3000 h−1, 7 ± 1 mg·m−3). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Experimental evaluation results of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn, 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce, 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co catalysts (GSHV=3000 h−1, 7 ± 1 mg·m−3). Fig. 12 Fig. 13 Experimental evaluation results of 0.1Pt/5Mn-5Ti catalysts with different GHSV. The catalytic oxidation method demonstrates efficient elimination of low-concentration formaldehyde in this study. Due to the low specific surface area, suboptimal surface structure, limited adsorption and storage capacity, and insufficient redox activity of single-component supports, other metals are incorporated into monometallic oxide supports to construct composite architectures.The combustion method refers to the preparation of catalytic materials by redox reaction using organic matter as reductant and metal nitrate as oxidant. The effects of the loading amount of metal introduced into the support TiO2 and the doped metal species on the physicochemical properties of the catalyst and the catalytic performance of the HCHO oxidation reaction were investigated. The results showed that with the increase of Mn content, the concentration of oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species of the catalyst increased, which was conducive to improving the catalyst's performance. However, with the further increase of Mn content, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased, the pores were blocked and the number of active oxygen species decreased, leading to a decrease in the catalytic performance. Compared with the Mn-doped catalyst, the Co and Ce doped catalysts exhibited a significantly lower proportion of surface-active oxygen species. Therefore the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst activity was better than the other two catalysts. The 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst was the most active when the Mn doping was 50 %, and it was able to achieve the complete conversion of 7 mg·m−3 formaldehyde at 50 ºC. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalytic oxidation Composite support Combustion method Active oxygen species Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Formaldehyde (HCHO), also known as anthranilic aldehyde, was discovered by German chemist Hoffmann in 1862. At room temperature and pressure, formaldehyde is a colorless organic compound, slightly heavier than air, soluble in water, and any small molecule organic solvent mixture. Formaldehyde solution (more than 60 %) at low temperature for a long time, it is easy to polymerize into paraformaldehyde, and the solution is white and turbid. Formaldehyde is a major indoor pollutant, which widely originates from the depolymerization and sustained release of paraformaldehyde from decoration materials such as artificial panels[1]. Numerous studies have shown that formaldehyde is exceeded in indoor environments such as homes, offices, and public places and that excessive formaldehyde in indoor environments due to home renovation is strongly associated with the development of leukemia in children and the elderly. Therefore, it is necessary to develop effective methods to eliminate formaldehyde. The main methods for indoor formaldehyde removal are ventilation[2], plasma air purification[3,4], photocatalytic oxidation[5], and catalytic oxidation. Among them, the ventilation method aims to reduce formaldehyde concentration through indoor-outdoor air exchange, which is simple and easy to implement, but difficult to apply in areas with difficult ventilation and mountainous environments. The plasma air purification method has a good purification effect and strong management ability, but the purification process consumes a lot of energy and causes secondary pollution. Photocatalytic oxidation technology is the use of light energy to stimulate semiconductor materials for the oxidation and reduction of electrons and holes, which has been widely researched and realized in several technologies, but its application scenarios are limited due to the intensity of light and the characteristics of the light source. The catalytic oxidation method involves the reaction of formaldehyde with oxygen in air in the presence of a catalyst to convert it to H2O and CO2. This method has the advantages of simple operation, high conversion efficiency, no secondary pollution, strong purification ability, low relative cost, and good purification effect, and it is currently the hottest research field in the field of formaldehyde purification. The catalytic oxidation method of Pt/TiO2 catalysts has good catalytic performance, which is attributed to the better dispersion of platinum on the support with smaller particle size to show more active sites, and TiO2 has the advantages of high reducibility, lattice oxygen enrichment, and electron synergistic effect. The catalytic oxidation mechanism of Pt/TiO2 catalysts has been extensively studied by several researchers. Naser et al.[6]employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate and compare the oxidation mechanisms of formaldehyde (HCHO) on nickel-doped carbon/silicon nanocages, iron-doped carbon/aluminum nitride nanocages, and copper-doped carbon/boron phosphide nanocages (Ni-C₅₀, Ni-Si₅₀, Fe-C₇₂, Fe-Al₃₆N₃₆, Cu-C₈₂, Cu-B₄₁P₄₁). Formaldehyde initially adsorbs onto the metal active sites via the O atom, forming the HHCOO intermediate. Subsequently, in Pathway 1, the rate-determining step involves the conversion of HCOO to HCO, followed by decomposition to CO and eventual oxidation to CO₂. Alternatively, Pathway 2 proceeds via the direct conversion of HCOO to CO₂. The Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) for all elementary reaction steps were calculated to be negative, indicating spontaneous reaction progression. Among the catalysts studied, Ni-Si₅₀, Fe-Al₃₆N₃₆, and Cu-B₄₁P₄₁ nanocages exhibited superior catalytic performance, attributed to their higher adsorption energies (ΔEₐdₛ) and lower reaction energy barriers (Eₐcₜ). This demonstrates their potential as efficient catalysts for formaldehyde oxidation. Saadh et al.[7]studied and compared the oxidation reaction pathway of formaldehyde on metal-doped nanocages (Fe-Si₄₆, Zn-C₄₆, Zn-Ge₄₆, Cu-Si₇₆, Co-C₇₆, and Co-B₃₈N₃₈) using density functional theory at the B3LYP/cc-pVQZ level. Formaldehyde adsorbs onto the active metal sites (Fe, Co, Zn, or Cu atoms), forming the HHCOO intermediate. This intermediate subsequently converts to HCOO. On nanocages with higher catalytic activity, such as Co-B₃₈N₃₈, HCOO further decomposes to HCO and CO, which is ultimately oxidized to CO₂. Batoo et al.[8]investigated and compared the degradation reaction pathway of tetracycline (TC) on a magnetically separable g-C₃N₄/TiO₂/CuFe₂O₄ heterostructure utilizing response surface methodology (RSM) optimization and visible-light-driven photocatalysis. Tetracycline initially adsorbs onto the catalyst surface. Under visible light irradiation, holes (h⁺) and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) dominate the oxidation process. At optimized conditions (catalyst dosage: 13.99 mg, TC concentration: 20.01 ppm, pH: 5.5, irradiation time: 40 min), a degradation efficiency of 98.47 % was achieved, leading to the formation of small molecular degradation products. Sabir et al.[9]studied and compared the degradation reaction pathway of methylene blue (MB) on graphene-TiO₂ nanocomposites (containing 0 %, 25 %, 50 %, and 75 % graphene) synthesized via an ultrasound-assisted co-precipitation technique. Methylene blue adsorbs onto the catalyst surface, facilitated by electrostatic interactions and π-π stacking. Under visible light irradiation, photogenerated electrons are captured by graphene and transferred to adsorbed oxygen, generating superoxide radicals (•O₂⁻), while holes (h⁺) either directly oxidize MB or react with H₂O to produce hydroxyl radicals (•OH). At 50 % graphene content, the synergistic action of these active species resulted in a degradation efficiency of 98.29 %, yielding small, harmless molecular products. He et al.[10,11] investigated and compared the reaction history of formaldehyde on the surface of Pt, Rh, Pd, and Au catalysts deposited on TiO2 by using the in situ DRIFTS technique. Formaldehyde first formed DOM species on the catalyst surface, then formate species were formed, which were further decomposed to CO species on the more active Pt/TiO2 catalyst, and finally, CO2 was generated. Xu et al. [12] investigated the catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde over Pt/A1OOH catalysts using infrared techniques. The catalytic reaction history of formaldehyde on the catalyst was proposed. They suggested that formaldehyde binds to the hydroxyl group on the surface of the catalyst through hydrogen bonding, and oxygen adsorbs on the surface of Pt and splits into reactive oxygen radicals. The reactive oxygen on the surface of Pt attacks C and H on the formaldehyde molecule to form formate intermediate species. The hydroxyl groups adsorbed on the surface of Pt continue to oxidize the formate to CO₂ and H2O. Yan et al. [13] investigated the catalytic oxidation course of formaldehyde over Pt/Fh catalyst by the DRIFTS technique. Oxygen in the air adsorbed on the surface of Pt nanoparticles splits into reactive oxygen species, formaldehyde molecules combine with hydroxyl groups on the surface of the support by hydrogen bonding to form positively charged formaldehyde molecules, reactive oxygen attacks the electrophilic carbon atoms to form DOM, and another reactive oxygen attacks the C-H to form DOM formic acid species and hydroxyl groups. Formic acid is then further oxidized to form CO2 and H2O.Nie et al.[14,15] investigated the reaction history of formaldehyde catalytic oxidation over NaOH-modified Pt/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2-NS catalysts. Firstly formaldehyde was adsorbed on the hydroxyl group on the catalyst surface, which was oxidized to formic acid, which decomposed to CO and H2O, and finally, CO was oxidized to CO2. Recently, the group [16] investigated the catalytic oxidation course of formaldehyde over Pt/NiO catalysts. They believed that firstly, formaldehyde and oxygen molecules adsorbed onto the surface of the Pt/NiO catalyst, and reactive oxygen decomposed on the surface of Pt particles reacted with formaldehyde to form formic acid, which was further oxidized to carbonic acid and then decomposed to CO2 and H2O; or formic acid was directly decomposed to CO and H2O and then continued to be oxidized by reactive oxygen to CO2.Chen et al.[17,18] investigated the reaction history of formaldehyde catalytic oxidation over Pt/TiNT and Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts by in situ infrared technique. It was concluded that the reaction process of formaldehyde catalytic oxidation was divided into two steps: the storage step and the oxidation step. In the first step, chemisorbed formaldehyde and oxygen reacted to formate species, and then formate decomposed to CO and H2O; in the second step, CO reacted with chemisorbed oxygen to form CO2.Zhu et al. [19] investigated the halogen poisoning effect in the catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde over Pt/TiO2 catalysts at room temperature. During the oxidation course of formaldehyde, after the appearance of halide ions, the empty orbitals of Pt atoms can also promote the transfer of electrons from halide ions to Pt atoms, resulting in the formation of Pt-X coordination bonds. Oxygen molecules on the surface of Pt nanoparticles could not replace the halide ions because the bonding energy of Pt-X was higher than that of Pt-O bonding, and the occupation of the active site by the halide ions prevented the adsorption and activation of the oxygen molecules, which led to the deactivation of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst. In this study, we prepared Pt/Ti-Mn catalysts with different manganese contents based on TiO2 supports by introducing transition metal Mn using the impregnation combustion method. The Pt/Ti-Mn, Pt/Ti-Ce, and Pt/Ti-Co catalysts doped with different transition metal oxides were prepared by over optimizing the metal species. The catalyst structures and chemical properties were investigated by various characterizations, and the effects of the metal species in the composite support and the ratio of the two metals on the catalytic activity were explored and explained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Calculate the mass of titanium oxide and manganese oxide based on the mass ratio of TiO2 and MnO2. The total mass of TiO2 and MnO2 is controlled to remain constant, the corresponding MnO2 mass is derived, and the corresponding manganese nitrate mass is calculated. Based on the theory of propellant chemistry proposed by Jain et al., the feed ratios of manganese nitrate and urea were calculated according to the molar ratios of total oxidized and total reduced values in the preparation process and the mass of urea was calculated based on the mass of manganese nitrate. Taking the introduction of manganese oxides as 50 % as an example, 2.50 g of anatase TiO2 was weighed and put on weighing paper, 2.87 g of urea and 5.14 g of manganese nitrate were put on standby, manganese nitrate and urea were added to a beaker, and distilled water was added and stirred to dissolve them. TiO2 was slowly added to the nitrate solution and sealed with cling film to avoid the disappearance of water in the beaker by evaporation during catalyst preparation, and the above precursor suspension was impregnated and stirred for 24 h. The catalysts were then mixed with the nitrate solution to avoid the disappearance of water by evaporation. The precursor suspension at the end of impregnation was placed in a preheated muffle furnace for reaction. The prepared precursor suspension was spontaneously combusted after standing for some time in a muffle furnace, and when the combustion reaction was finished and the muffle furnace cooled down naturally, the prepared product was collected and set aside. Add an appropriate amount of chloroplatinic acid solution to the beaker. Add the above 5 g of support to the chloroplatinic acid solution (so that the loading of Pt is 0.1 %), and stir for 1 h. Take 1.0 g of NaOH in a beaker, add water to dissolve it, weigh another 0.19 g of NaBH4 in the NaOH solution, and fix in a volumetric flask. Take the mixture solution and add it to the above solution, heat and stir, then remove it. Oven dry at 120°C for 12 h, and remove it after cooling down. The prepared catalyst was sieved to 20–40 mesh and set aside, noted as 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn. Concerning the method, composite support catalysts with different manganese contents (10 %, 30 %, 70 %, and 90 % introduction of manganese oxides, respectively), denoted as 0.1Pt/1Ti-9Mn, 0.1Pt/3Ti-7Mn, 0.1Pt/7Ti-3Mn, 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn, were prepared. According to the above method, catalysts with 50 % doping of cobalt and cerium oxides were prepared, which were denoted as 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystal shape, crystallinity and dispersion of the loaded metals of the catalysts in the experiments were studied using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE A25 X-ray diffractometer. The experimental conditions were as follows: Scanning was performed using Cu targets (Kα rays, λ = 1.54 Å) at a tube pressure of 40 kv and a tube current of 40 mA. The 2θ scans of the XRD spectra of the characterisation results are in the 5–90° interval. The pore structure characterisation of the catalysts prepared in this study was carried out on a TristarII mesoporous physisorbent apparatus. The catalysts to be tested were first desorbed at 200°C and 1.33 Pa for 6 h, and then liquid nitrogen was contacted with the N2 adsorbent to reach equilibrium. The amount of adsorbed nitrogen of the catalyst to be tested was calculated based on the difference between the nitrogen intake and the adsorption residue during the experimental operation, and the specific surface area (SBET) and the pore volume (VP) of the catalysts were obtained by the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method, and the adsorption isotherm was determined by the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halanda) method. pore size distribution (Dp) of the catalyst on the adsorption isotherm. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) operations were performed at wavelengths from 4000 to 400 cm−1 using a German Bruker VERTEX 70 instrument. The surface properties of the catalyst samples were determined by an AXIS ULTRA DLD type X-ray photoelectron spectrometer from Quitos, UK, using Al Kα as the radiation source. The morphological characteristics, particle size and dispersion status of the catalysts were determined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) characterisation, and the SEM characterisation of the catalysts in this study was carried out on a JSM-7900F instrument in Japan. The Hydrogen Programmed Temperature Reduction is operated using a Syngenta TP-5000 instrument. Before measurement, 100 mg was accurately weighed into a sample tube, pre-treated for 30 min at 300°C in an N2 atmosphere of 30 mL·min−1 (to remove surface water and CO2), cooled to room temperature in an N2 atmosphere, and stabilised for 30 min in 5 % H2/N2 for reduction at a ramp rate of 10 °C·min−1. Oxygen programmed thermal desorption (O2-TPD) was carried out using the same equipment as H2-TPR, with 100 mg of sample pre-treated with He/H2 at 300°C for 60 min, followed by cooling to room temperature (25°C) under He, adsorption under 5 % O2/He for 60 min, and then He blowing for 60 min, followed by desorption under pure He (25–800°C). The microstructure and morphology of the catalysts were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument operated at 200 kV, with an imaging resolution of 1.9 Å. In situ DRIFTS was carried out on a German VERTEX 80 v instrument to examine the intermediates and reaction pathways produced during the oxidative formaldehyde transformation of formaldehyde. The samples to be examined were placed in an infrared in situ cell and pretreated with dry He at 300 °C at a flow rate of 30 mL·min−1 for 1 h to remove the water, and then cooled down to room temperature in a He atmosphere.The background spectrum of the catalyst was collected in an inert atmosphere, and the formaldehyde vapour was brought in by the bubble method, and the spectrum was recorded in the reaction atmosphere (HCHO, 20 % O2, He equilibrium gas) at a flow rate of 30 mL·min−1 into the reaction cell with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The HCHO catalytic oxidation reaction was operated in a fixed bed reactor under atmospheric pressure, 4.0 g of catalyst (sieve fraction 350–833 μm) was loaded in the reactor. The HCHO solution was pumped into the heating tube, heated and vaporized at 120 °C. The air carries the HCHO vapor (about (3 ± 0.5) mg·L−1) and some of the steam into the reaction tower of the fixed bed reactors, The total flow rate was 100 mL·min−1, corresponding to space velocity (GSHV) of 3000 h−1. The initial HCHO concentration and the final HCHO concentration after the reaction were detected by the combination of the air extraction pump and the formaldehyde reaction tube. (1) C onversion of HCHO = H CHO i − [ H CHO ] f [ H CHO ] i × 100 % where [HCHO]i (mg·L−1) is the initial concentration of HCHO before the test started, and [HCHO]f (mg·L−1) is the final concentration of HCHO at the end of the test. 3 Results and Discussions 3.1 Microstructure of catalysts The composite support precursors with different manganese contents were burned to form a gray-black solid, the morphology of which is shown in Fig. 1. The 9Ti-1Mn support produced by the combustion process has a granular macroscopic morphology as can be seen in the figure. With the gradual increase of manganese content in the precursor during the preparation process, the particles of the combustion products increase in size, interconnect,and exhibit a loose and porous structure. When the content of Mn oxides in the composite support reaches more than 70 %, the combustion product morphology is more fluffy and shows a rich hierarchical structure. SEM characterization results of Pt/Mn-Ti catalysts with different manganese contents are shown in Fig. 2. From the characterization results, it was seen that the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst without Mn doping had a distinct spherical microscopic morphology, with microsphere particles of about 30–50 nm in diameter and smooth and flat particle surfaces. In the 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalyst doped with 10 % manganese oxides,spherical particle morphology is still observed, but the difference in particle diameter increases and the particle surface becomes rough. As the content of Mn oxides in the composite support increases further, the catalyst particles become more irregular and it is even difficult to recognize the spherical structure of the particles. When the content of Mn oxides in the composite support was further increased to 90 %, the catalyst could no longer be seen as obvious spherical particles and showed the morphology of irregular solid structure stacking. Fig. 3 shows the XRD characterization results of 0.1 Pt/Ti-Mn series catalysts doped with different levels of manganese oxides. The undoped 0.1Pt/Ti catalysts with Mn oxides had sharp characteristic diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 at 2θ = 25.3°, 48.0°, and 62.7° (PDF No. 86–1157), which indicated anatase crystalline TiO2 in the support. After the addition of manganese oxide metal fraction, there were MnO2, Mn2O3,and Mn3O4 diffraction peaks generated, which indicated that manganese oxide phases with different valence states of + 3, + 4,and + 8/3 valence existed simultaneously in the modified support. With the gradual increase of the Mn oxide content in the composite support, the intensity of the diffraction peaks of the Mn oxide phase gradually increased, while the intensity of the diffraction peaks of the TiO2 phase gradually decreased, which is consistent with the trend of the increase of the Mn component content and the decrease of the Ti component content in the support. The characteristic diffraction peaks of Pt species are not present in the figure, indicating that there is no obvious crystallization of Pt species present in the catalyst, and the Pt in the catalyst is well dispersed. Table 1 shows the pore structure parameters of the samples. The specific surface area of the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst with TiO2 as the support was 75.6 m2·g−1 with an average pore size of 17.3 nm and an average pore volume of 0.33 cm3/g. After the introduction of 10 % Mn species in the support, the specific surface area of the 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalyst increased to 101.6 m2·g−1 with the rise of the surface roughness of the TiO2 particles, but there was also a blockage of the pores on the inner surface of the TiO2 particles, and the average pore diameter and average pore volume decreased slightly. When the content of Mn oxides in the composite support continued to increase, the blockage of the support pores gradually increased, and the pore structure characteristics of the catalysts such as SBET, Vpore,and Dpore decreased. Compared with the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalysts, the specific surface areas of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co catalysts were smaller, only 43.4 m2·g−1 and 26.5 m2·g−1, respectively. Fig. 4 shows the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distribution curves for the catalyst. From Fig. 4 it is seen that the catalyst has type IV adsorption equilibrium isotherms [20,21], which indicates that the catalyst has a mesoporous structure. The presence of H3-type hysteresis loops in the range of relative pressures P/P0 = 0.4–1.0 [20,21], indicates the presence of aggregates with a lamellar structure of the catalyst, producing slit mesoporous or macroporous materials with the typical characteristics of non-rigid aggregates of lamellar particles as slit pores formed by lamellar particles stacking [20,21], confirms that manganese oxides are introduced mainly by stacking on the TiO2 surface. From Fig. 4(a), it is obvious that the hysteresis loop of the catalyst gradually becomes smaller with the gradual increase of Mn doping during catalyst preparation, which is caused by the decrease of the specific surface area of the catalyst due to the accumulation of a large number of Mn oxide particles on the surface. As seen in Fig. 4(b), the doping of metal oxides during the preparation process has a significant effect on the adsorption and desorption isotherms, and when doped into the same mass of Mn, Co, and Ce, the hysteresis loop of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn is greater than the other two, which indicates that the effect of the buildup of Mn particles is small, confirming that the specific surface area of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn is greater than that of the other metal-doped catalysts, and Table 1 results correspond. The pore size distribution curve determined the pore size distribution of the samples, as shown in Fig. 4(c), the undoped 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst has a large number of mesopores in the range of 10–40 nm, and the maximum pore size is 24 nm, which confirms the existence of the mesopores, and further proves that the catalyst is mesoporous. When 10 % Mn was doped into the support, the maximum pore size of the 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn and 0.1Pt/Ti catalysts were similar, and with the increase of the proportion of doped Mn, the maximum pore size of the catalysts was gradually reduced, and the maximum pore size of the 0.1Pt/1Ti-9Mn catalyst was only 13 nm, which may be due to the buildup of Mn particles on the surface of the catalysts resulting in the reduction of the pore size, which corresponds to the trend of average pore size of the catalysts in Table 1, which corresponds to the trend of the average pore size of the catalyst. As seen in Fig. 4(d), the doping of metals during the preparation process has a significant effect on the change of pore size, and when doped into the same mass of Mn, Co, and Ce, the maximum pore size of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co catalyst is larger than that of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce catalysts, which is consistent with the results of the average pore size characterization of the catalysts in Table 1. Fig. 5 shows TEM images and elemental distribution maps of the calcined, post-treated 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst containing smaller Pt particles. By measuring the lattice fringes of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn (Fig. 5(a)), lattice spacings of approximately 0.196, 0.35, 0.288, 0.27, and 0.49 nm were determined. Among these, the lattice spacing of 0.196 nm corresponds to the (200) crystal plane of Pt; the lattice spacing of 0.35 nm corresponds to the (101) crystal plane of TiO₂; the lattice spacing of 0.288 nm corresponds to the (200) crystal plane of Mn₃O₄; the lattice spacing of 0.27 nm originates from the (222) crystal plane of Mn₂O₃; and the lattice spacing of 0.49 nm is due to the (200) crystal plane of MnO₂. The elemental distribution maps shown in Fig. 5(b-d) clearly indicate that Pt, Ti, and Mn elements are uniformly dispersed in the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn sample. As shown in Fig. 5(e), the Pt-containing catalyst exhibits relatively uniformly distributed particles with an average size of 2.35 nm. 3.2 Chemical properties of catalysts The FT-IR characterization of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 6. From the figure, it can be seen that there is a broad vibrational peak present at 3445 cm−1, which is generated by the telescopic vibration of the -OH groups on the catalyst surface or physically adsorbed water [22]; and the bending vibrational peak at 1633 cm−1 belongs to the -OH [23], which is because the catalysts were dried before the characterization, and from this the presence of -OH groups on the surface of the catalysts is determined. The broad band centered at 500–600 cm−1 in the figure corresponds to the bending vibrational peak of Ti-O in the TiO2 lattice [24], which corresponds to TiO2 in the support. The peak at 523 cm−1 corresponds to the Mn-O vibrational peak [25], which suggests that the catalyst contains manganese oxides present. As can be seen from the H2-TPR results for the catalyst in Fig. 7, the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst produced a reduction peak at 448°C, which corresponds to the TiO2 reduction peak as seen. This is due to the dispersed Pt metal particles on the surface of the TiO2 support promoting hydrogen adsorption, the presence of intermetallic electronic synergistic effect at high temperatures, and the transformation of Ti4+ in contact with the metal Pt to Ti3+ under the action of H(ads) [26]. After doping with transition metal oxides, the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce catalysts also had TiO2 reduction peaks present and the peak positions were shifted to the right compared to the undoped 0.1Pt/Ti catalysts, which was caused by the flow of H(ads) to the surface of the more reducible transition metal oxides. The Co-doped catalyst had no TiO2 reduction peak. For the 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn series catalysts, the reduction temperature of TiO2 in the 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalysts was 484°C, which increased from 484°C to 533°C when the Mn oxide content in the composite support was increased to 70 %. It is possible that most of the H(ads) that originally flowed to the TiO2 surface flowed to the more reducible MnOx surface [27], increasing the reduction temperature of TiO2. In addition, the 0.1Pt/Ti-Ce catalyst produces a reduction peak at 362°C, which matches the reduction of Ceδ+ in the literature [28], there is a Coδ+ hydrogen depletion peak at 419°C for the 0.1Pt/Ti-Co catalyst, and the 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn catalyst is a reduction of Mnδ+ at 360°C. For the 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn series catalysts, the 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalysts did not produce significant Mn oxide reduction peaks due to the low manganese content in the support preparation process. With the increase in the specific gravity of Mn oxides during the preparation process, the 0.1Pt/7Ti-3Mn catalyst started to produce a distinct MnOx reduction peak at around 360°C, which is known from the literature to result from the partial overlap of three reduction peaks corresponding to the multiple redox process [29]: MnO2/Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 → MnO [30]. The reduction peak temperature (360°C) of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst is lower than that of the catalysts doped with other contents of Mn oxides as seen in the figure, which suggests that the catalyst has superior reducibility and is capable of generating more oxygen vacancies [30,31]. Gas-phase oxygen can be adsorbed on the surface oxygen vacancies to generate a large number of reactive oxygen species via electron transfer, which improves the catalytic reaction activity [32,33]. Pt can form Pt0, Pt2+, Pt4+,and other species on the support [34], based on the literature, it is proved that the reduction temperature of Pt is below 250°C [35], and it can be decomposed at 300°C [36] , due to the low content of Pt species in the catalyst, and most of them are in the reduced state, there is no obvious platinum oxide reduction peak. O2-TPD characterization inferred the surface oxygen species of the catalyst [30]. From literature investigation [35,37], it is known that the order of adsorption of oxygen species on the catalyst surface is oxygen molecule (O2) > oxygen molecule ion (O2 -) > oxygen ion (O-) > lattice oxygen (O2-). Oxygen molecules are usually adsorbed on the catalyst surface at less than 200°C, while the adsorption temperatures of reactive oxygen species O2 -, O-, etc. are usually between 200 and 400°C, with the highest adsorption temperatures for lattice oxygens, which are usually more than 400°C [38,39]. From Fig. 8, it is seen that the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst has a weak absorption peak at 208°C, which corresponds to the adsorption peak of oxygen molecules, and the adsorption peaks of reactive oxygen species O2 -, O- and so on were generated at 385°C, which has a small area, which is the reason for the poor activity of this catalyst. The 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalyst also produced an oxygen molecule adsorption peak at 203°C. With the increase of the specific gravity of Mn oxides in the preparation process, the adsorption peaks of oxygen molecules on the catalyst surface gradually disappeared, the position of the active oxygen species peaks shifted to the left, i.e., the temperature of the peaks decreased, and the area of the adsorption peaks increased with the increase of specific gravity of the introduced Mn, and the adsorption peaks of the active oxygen species were produced by the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalysts at 333 °C. When the Mn oxide content in the composite support continued to increase, the peak position showed a rightward shift, and the adsorption peaks of reactive oxygen species were produced only at 345°C for the 0.1Pt/1Ti-9Mn catalyst, which was caused by the poor reducing property of this catalyst. The oxygen desorption temperature is closely related to the activity of the catalyst; the lower the resolution temperature, the easier it is to produce reactive oxygen species. Reactive oxygen species can accelerate catalytic reactions[40] and are key factors influencing catalytic activity. In addition, Huang et al. [35] found that oxygen vacancies can accelerate the generation of reactive oxygen species, and the H2-TPR characterization results proved that the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst can generate more oxygen vacancies, and a better catalytic activity can be expected for the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst [30]. Fig. 9 shows the XPS characterization done to explore the surface chemistry of the catalyst elements. From the full XPS spectrum of the catalyst in Fig. 9(a), we can get the binding energy peaks of the catalyst containing Na 1 s, Mn 2p, O 1 s, Ti 2p, and Pt 4 f orbitals, which indicates the presence of Na, Mn, O, Ti, and Pt elements in the catalyst. Among them, the Mn element is derived from MnOx in the support, all Ti elements are derived from TiO2 in the support, O elements are mainly derived from lattice oxygen and surface hydroxyl groups, Pt elements are derived from loaded metal Pt, and Na elements are derived from the addition of NaOH and NaBH4 in the pre-reduction process [41]. The presence of sodium (Na) exerts a dual influence on the catalyst performance. Excessive Na loading leads to significant catalyst agglomeration and non-uniform Pt particle distribution, resulting in a pronounced decline in catalytic activity[42,43]. However, an optimal residual Na content (ca. 1.64 wt%) was found to enhance both the catalytic activity and stability, likely through modification of the metal active sites[44,45]. In the present study, the Na content in the synthesized catalyst was determined to be approximately 1.3 wt%. Based on these findings, this controlled level of residual Na is not anticipated to detrimentally impact the catalyst performance. The Mn 2p peak splitting results of the catalyst are shown in Fig. 9(b), and based on the literature review [46–48], the binding energies at 642.7–643.1 eV correspond to Mn4+, 641.1–641.5 eV to Mn3+, and 640.5–640.7 eV to Mn2+. As shown in Table 2, the binding energies of Mn4+, Mn3+, and Mn2+ all tended to increase as the specific gravity of manganese oxides increased during preparation. Given that the binding energy of the 3 s polyploid splitting of the manganese ion depends on the number of 3d electrons [49,50], the Mn 3 s energy spectrum can be more sensitively resolved for the oxidation state of manganese, and the Mn 3 s results for the catalyst are shown in Fig. 9(e). The average oxidation state (AOS) of elemental manganese was calculated based on the energy level difference of Mn 3 s [51] as shown in Table 2, which shows that both the energy level difference of E3s and the average oxidation state of manganese of the catalyst increase with the increase of manganese metal doping, and the energy level difference of E3s 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn is about 4.88 eV with an AOS of 2.89, while that of E3s 0.1Pt /1Ti-9Mn energy level difference then rises to 5.39 eV with the energy level difference of 3.46 eV, which indicates that the amount of missing electrons in the 3d orbitals of manganese is proportional to the amount of manganese doping, and also indicates that the valence of manganese gradually increases. The AOS values of the catalysts were all lower than those of MnO2 as seen in Table 2 [49,50] , which proves that Mn3+ is present in large quantities with the catalysts. The higher amount of Mn3+ proves that the catalyst has a higher number of oxygen vacancies, which can better promote oxygen adsorption to produce reactive oxygen species[52]. It can improve the catalytic reaction activity. Two oxygen species diffraction peaks can be seen from the XPS peak splitting results of catalyst O 1 s in Fig. 9(c). The O 1 s peaks at 529.5–530.0 eV are lattice oxygen species (O I) in the Ti-Mn support; 531.7–532.0 eV are adsorbed oxygen species (O II) on the catalyst surface [53,54]. As seen through Table 2, the O I peak position of the 0.1 Pt/Ti catalyst is at 529.9 eV. With the introduction of Mn oxides in the support, the catalyst OⅠ peak position was shifted to the right, and the 0.1Pt/3Ti-7Mn catalyst OⅠ peak position was 529.6 eV. The OII peak of the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst was at 531.4 eV, and with the increase of Mn content, the catalyst OII peak position showed the same rightward shifting trend, and the OII peak position of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst was at 531.3 eV. The rightward shift of the electronic energy level may be due to oxygen adsorption at the defect site leading to electron transfer [55]. The results of the catalyst surface active oxygen molar ratio calculation are shown in Table 2, the OII/OⅠ+OⅡ value of 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst is 24 %, after doping manganese, the surface oxygen species percentage of 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalyst rises to 48 %, which means that the doping of manganese oxides makes the surface oxygen species of the catalyst more enriched, and with the continuous increase of manganese oxides, the surface oxygen species percentage of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst rises to a maximum of 55 %. Oxygen species on the catalyst surface have a pivotal effect on the catalytic oxidation reaction [56−58], which is the main reason for the increase in catalyst activity after manganese doping. The results of the Ti 2p spectra of the catalyst are shown in Fig. 9(d), and the characteristic peak energy level of Ti 2p3/2 of Ti is near 458.7 eV [44]. After manganese doping, the specific gravity of TiO2 in the support decreases and the intensity of the diffraction peaks of Ti gradually decreases. The binding energy of Ti 2p3/2 for the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst increased to 458.6 eV from 458.4 eV for the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst, and the increase in the binding energy of Ti 2p3/2 may be caused by the electron transfer between different valence states of Mn resulting in the loss of electrons on the Ti surface. As shown in Fig. 9(e), the Pt 4 f spectrum of the catalyst has two distinct diffraction peaks near 72.4 and 75.6 eV, which correspond to the 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2 orbitals of Pt2+, respectively [59]. In addition, a Pt0 diffraction peak was present at 70.6 eV for the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst, and the Mn-doped catalyst did not produce an obvious Pt0 diffraction peak, but a 4 f5/2 diffraction peak of Pt4+ was present near 77.8 eV, which might be caused by the reduction of some Mn elements by NaBH4. Fig. 10 shows the XPS results for the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5M (M=Mn, Co, Ce) catalyst. the characteristic peak of Ti 2p3/2 is at 458.4 eV, and the binding energies of Ti 2p3/2 for the three catalysts after the introduction of the transition metal oxides are 458.8 eV (0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co), 458.6 eV (0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn), and 458.5 eV (0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce), respectively. It can be seen that the binding energy of the catalyst Ti 2p3/2 is significantly higher, which may be due to the electron loss on the Ti surface as a result of electron transfer between different metals. Two oxygen species diffraction peaks, lattice oxygen species (OⅠ) and surface adsorbed oxygen species (OⅡ), were seen from the O 1 s spectra of the catalysts. The OⅠ peak and OⅡ peak positions of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co catalyst were 530.1 eV and 531.6 eV, respectively, which were significantly higher than those of 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst (529.8 eV, 531.3 eV) and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce catalyst (529.6 eV, 531.4 eV). the low energy levels might be produced by the catalyst surface of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface resulted. It can also be seen that the OII peak area of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst is larger than that of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce catalysts, which implies that there is more reactive oxygen on the surface of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst, which is the reason why the catalytic activity of the catalyst is better than the other two catalysts. 3.3 Reaction properties of catalysts The results of formaldehyde oxidation evaluation of 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn series catalysts at 25–150°C are shown in Fig. 11. The undoped Mn 0.1 Pt/Ti catalyst showed a formaldehyde conversion of 70 % at room temperature (25°C), which increased to 98 % when the temperature was raised to 150°C. The introduction of Mn oxides in the support resulted in a significant increase in catalytic activity. The conversion of formaldehyde over the 0.1Pt/9Ti-1Mn catalyst increased to 92 % at 25°C. The catalyst activity gradually increased with the increase in the specific gravity of Mn oxides, and the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst could realize the complete conversion of formaldehyde at 50°C (at which time the concentration of the exhaust gas was lower than 0.02 mg·m−3). Formaldehyde conversion has reached 98 % at room temperature. When the content of Mn oxides in the composite support continued to rise, the specific surface area of the catalyst gradually decreased, the number of surface hydroxyl groups and active oxygen species decreased, the catalyst activity decreased, and the formaldehyde complete conversion temperature of the 0.1Pt/3Ti-7Mn catalyst increased to 125 °C. As the Mn oxide content in the composite support continued to increase, the 0.1Pt/1Ti-9Mn catalyst showed a conversion of 98 % at 150°C and a low 93 % conversion of formaldehyde at room temperature. The results of the evaluation of the catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde at 25–150°C over different metal-doped 0.1Pt/Ti-M (M=Mn, Co, Ce) catalysts prepared by impregnation combustion method are shown in Fig. 12. As can be seen in Fig. 12, the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce catalyst achieves complete conversion of formaldehyde at 125°C and still has 96 % conversion at room temperature (25°C). The catalytic activity of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co catalyst was slightly poorer, and complete conversion of formaldehyde was only possible at 150°C under the same conditions. The catalytic activity of the 0.1 Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst was better than that of the above catalysts, which had a complete conversion of formaldehyde at 50°C and also converted 98 % of formaldehyde at room temperature. The formaldehyde conversion of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst in the range of 1500–19,500 h−1 airspeed interval at 50°C under reaction conditions with an initial formaldehyde concentration of 7 mg·m−3 is shown in Fig. 13. The formaldehyde conversion of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst converged to 100 % when the airspeed was 7500 h−1. When the airspeed was increased to 19500 h−1, the reaction conversion decreased to 90 %, which was attributed to the decrease in conversion due to the shrinkage of the contact time between the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst and formaldehyde when the reaction airspeed was increased. It can be seen that the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst still possesses high formaldehyde conversion at higher air velocity. 3.4 Study on catalytic reaction mechanism To investigate the formaldehyde catalytic reaction mechanism, the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst was characterized by in situ DRIFTS and the results of the characterization are shown in Fig. 14. As can be seen in Fig. 14(a), after the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst was placed in the HCHO/O2 environment for 2 min of reaction, there was a weak vibrational peak at 2359 cm−1, which was caused by the oxidation of formaldehyde to produce CO2 [60,61], and the intensity of the CO2 vibrational peak was gradually strengthened with the increase of the catalytic reaction time, which corresponded to the substance of the reaction. After 5 min of catalyst reaction, two distinct spectral peaks appeared at ca. 3403 cm−1 and ca. 1645 cm−1, corresponding to the telescopic vibrational peaks of the hydroxyl group of water formed during the oxidation of formaldehyde [33,62], and the intensities of the two peaks gradually increased with the increase of reaction time as more HCHO was oxidized, which may be due to the generation of more H2O during the reaction process resulting from [62]. In addition to this, after 5 min of reaction, vibrational peaks appeared at 2950, 2833 cm−1, which were generated by the ν(CH) vibration of formate (HCOO-) [29,60,62], the symmetric telescoping vibrational peaks (νas) at 1573 cm−1 corresponded to the COO of formate species [63], and the symmetric telescoping vibrational at 1226 cm−1 corresponded to the ν(CO) of formate species [62]. The δ(CH2) and ν(CO) vibrational peaks of dimethoxymethyl (DOM) species are at 1100 cm−1 [29] and 1456 cm−1 [62], respectively, and dominate with increasing HCHO exposure time. A vibrational peak at 1037 cm−1 was found for the carbonate with a double coordination group. The 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst without Mn doping can be seen through Fig. 14 (b) that the same species vibrational peaks consistent with the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst are present at positions 3433, 2950, 2833, 2359, 1573, 1456, 1293, 1200, and 1141 cm−1. Comparative tests were carried out on 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalysts purified by adding an HCHO/He mixture followed by pure O2 to examine the significance of gaseous O2 in the oxidation of formaldehyde. Fig. 14 (c) shows the same vibrational peaks at 2950, 2833, 1573, 1456, 1226, and 1100 cm−1, corresponding to the production of DOM and formaldehyde salt species. This shows that HCHO can produce DOM and formate even without O2 gas. This phenomenon was similarly observed in catalysts such as Pt/MnO2/TiNT, and PtC@MnO2 [29,64]. The intensity of DOM and formate peaks also increased rapidly during the reaction time of 10–30 min, indicating that a large amount of DOM and formate accumulated on the catalyst surface. In addition, vibrational peaks of CO2 and H2O can be seen, where CO2 and some of the H2O are produced in the catalyzed reaction, and some of the H2O is carried in the formaldehyde solution. After purification by passing pure O2, as shown in Fig. 14 (d), there was no significant change in the intensity of vibrational peaks of DOM and formate and the intensity of vibrational peaks of CO2 was significantly enhanced during the 30 min reaction time, which indicates that the formate and DOM produced by the reaction can be easily converted into CO2 under the condition of sufficient gaseous O2. This suggests that reaction intermediates such as formate and DOM produced by the catalyst no longer produce accumulation upon introduction of gaseous O2, but are rapidly oxidized to CO2, releasing active sites for further oxidation of formaldehyde. Based on the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism and the above characterization results, a possible reaction mechanism for the catalytic oxidation of HCHO at low concentration over 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst is proposed in this study. During the reaction, formaldehyde and O2 were first adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and due to the fast reaction rate, no obvious HCHO vibrational peaks existed in the INSITU DRIFTS spectra [62]. Gas-phase oxygen molecules adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface generate reactive oxygen species (O2+V0→O2 -, O-) by the action of electrons generated by the oxidation reaction between Mn3+ and Mn4+ [29,33,65], while at the same time,the electrons of the reactive oxygen species are transferred into Mn4+ to generate Mn3+ by reduction. In addition, gas-phase oxygen with Pt nanoparticles generates a large number of Pt-O active centers, releasing many surface-active oxygen species through the interaction between the metal and the support [29,68]. According to the MVK mechanism, formaldehyde adsorbed on the catalyst surface reacts with reactive oxygen species to generate DOM reaction intermediates, and DOM subsequently decomposes to produce formate species, which reacts with reactive oxygen species to generate CO2 and H2O. Fig. 14(c) shows that the catalyst without oxygen also produces a certain amount of CO2, and the combination of FT-IR (Fig. 6) and XPS (Fig. 9) characterization shows that the catalyst surface itself contains a certain amount of hydroxyl groups. It is generally accepted that water molecules can dissociate on oxygen vacancies to form two hydroxyl groups [33], and the number of surface hydroxyl groups increases due to the large number of oxygen vacancies contained on the surface of the 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn catalyst. From this, it can be inferred that the second route of formaldehyde oxidation: H2O and reactive oxygen in the role of oxygen vacancies react to generate OH groups (O2 - + H2O → 2OH), HCHO can be in the role of surface active hydroxyl should be generated under the action of DOM and formic acid, and then part of the formic acid in the role of surface hydroxyl decomposition into CO2 and H2O. In summary, surface oxygen and oxygen vacancies are the main active substances in the catalytic process. Under aerobic conditions, capable of oxidizing HCHO to DOM, formate species, and then completely oxidizing to CO2 and H2O. The key to the catalytic reaction lies in the rapid replenishment of gaseous O2 with reactive oxygen species through dissociation, activation,and migration at noble metals as well as oxygen vacancies. On the contrary, under anoxic conditions, formaldehyde can be partially oxidized to form CO2 and H2O as seen in Fig. 14(c), but formate species accumulate significantly with reaction time, combined with Fig. 14(d), it can be seen that the introduction of oxygen makes the CO2 vibrational peaks significantly stronger, and it can be inferred that the reaction between HCHO and reactive oxygen is the main path of the catalytic reaction, and the reaction between HCHO and the surface hydroxyl group can be regarded as the auxiliary path. Wang et al. [66] summarized that the selectivity of HCHO for CO2 was greatlyenhanced in humid air, whereas in dry air, HCHO was mainly oxidized to CO, and therefore,there was no CO production in this case as in other reactions [29,53]. Through Fig. 14(b), it can be seen that the vibrational peaks of formate species on the surface of the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst are significantly stronger than those of the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst in Fig. 14(a), which means that there is a large amount of formate species accumulated on the surface of the 0.1Pt/Ti catalyst during the reaction process, and the lack of decomposition of formate will occupy the active sites of the catalyst and deactivate the catalytic reaction[65], which is the main reason for the poor activity of this catalyst. Meanwhile, the introduction of manganese led to the formation of many oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which promoted the generation of reactive oxygen species and enabled the improvement of the catalytic reaction conversion. From Fig. 11 we can see that the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst can convert formaldehyde up to 100 % at 150°C and 98 % at room temperature, which also implies that heating can promote the decomposition of the reaction intermediates and thus the release of the active sites to improve the catalyst's reactivity [65,67]. 4 Conclusion This study systematically reveals the critical regulatory role of manganese (Mn) doping content on the catalytic activity of 0.1Pt/Ti-Mn catalysts for formaldehyde oxidation. The key finding demonstrates that optimizing the Mn doping level (50 mol%) effectively modulates the Mn-Ti interaction. This optimization maximizes the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies and the population of active oxygen species, ultimately endowing the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst with superior catalytic activity compared to reference materials such as 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Co and 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Ce. This finding not only provides a clear strategy for designing efficient formaldehyde purification catalysts through precise regulation of Mn content to optimize active oxygen species but also deepens the understanding of the mechanistic role of synergistic effects between metal oxides (e.g., Mn-Ti) in influencing catalyst surface properties (oxygen vacancies, active oxygen) and reaction performance. Furthermore, it enriches the structure-activity relationship theory for multi-component catalysts. To advance this high-performance catalyst system from laboratory research towards practical implementation, future studies should urgently focus on exploring and optimizing catalyst scale-up processes, alongside conducting comprehensive performance evaluations under simulated real-world or actual application conditions. This approach is essential for translating the design principles revealed herein into effective solutions for air pollution control. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic oxidation method demonstrates efficient elimination of low-concentration formaldehyde in this study. Due to the low specific surface area, suboptimal surface structure, limited adsorption and storage capacity, and insufficient redox activity of single-component supports, other metals are incorporated into monometallic oxide supports to construct composite architectures.The combustion method refers to the preparation of catalytic materials by redox reaction using organic matter as reductant and metal nitrate as oxidant. The effects of the loading amount of metal introduced into the support TiO2 and the doped metal species on the physicochemical properties of the catalyst and the catalytic performance of the HCHO oxidation reaction were investigated. The results showed that with the increase of Mn content, the concentration of oxygen vacancies and active oxygen species of the catalyst increased, which was conducive to improving the catalyst's performance. However, with the further increase of Mn content, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased, the pores were blocked and the number of active oxygen species decreased, leading to a decrease in the catalytic performance. Compared with the Mn-doped catalyst, the Co and Ce doped catalysts exhibited a significantly lower proportion of surface-active oxygen species. Therefore the 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst activity was better than the other two catalysts. The 0.1Pt/5Ti-5Mn catalyst was the most active when the Mn doping was 50 %, and it was able to achieve the complete conversion of 7 mg·m−3 formaldehyde at 50 ºC.
